title: The Cognitive Effects of Lorazepam in Healthy Older Individuals With TOMM40 Variable-length Polymorphisms
description_brief: The investigators' goal is to determine if certain tests of memory and attention, performed while sleepiness is induced by a single dose of lorazepam, can predict whether or not an individual is at risk for developing Alzheimer's disease.
explanation_target: Reason: The trial uses a single dose of lorazepam to induce sleepiness and then measures memory/attention to predict future Alzheimer’s risk — this is a pharmacologic challenge / predictive diagnostic paradigm rather than a therapeutic intervention aimed at modifying disease, improving cognition, or treating neuropsychiatric symptoms. (Trial description provided by user.)

Act (drug & mechanism): Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine that acts as a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors, producing sedation and impairing memory/attention (anterograde amnesia, slowed reaction time), effects that are routinely used in pharmacologic challenge studies. citeturn0search3turn0search10turn0search0turn0search7

Act (genetic marker context): The TOMM40 variable‑length (poly‑T) polymorphism has been studied as a genetic marker associated with altered age‑of‑onset/risk for late‑onset Alzheimer’s disease and with subtle cognitive/brain differences in preclinical subjects — this explains why the investigators stratify/assess participants by TOMM40 in a predictive study. citeturn0search6turn0search2turn0search9

Reflect / Classification: Because the study’s goal is prediction using a pharmacologic challenge (lorazepam) and a genetic marker (TOMM40), and not to test a biologic or small molecule that targets Alzheimer pathology, nor to evaluate a cognitive‑enhancing therapy or a treatment for neuropsychiatric symptoms, it does not fit the four therapeutic target categories and is therefore classified as 'N/A'.
